title: Both liberals and conservatives claim the mainstream media is biased. Who is right? Why or why not? - Quora

response.answer_text: Both liberals and conservatives claim the mainstream media is biased. Who is right? Depends on the media service being talked about. If you watch, browse or listen to Fox News, your bias is definitely conservative. They claim to be fair and unbiased, but if you look closely at any of their stories, there is always a bent to make liberals and their policies look completely idiotic. If you watch, browse or listen to MSNBC, your bias is without question liberal. Conservatives and their policies are destructive and ready to bring the world to war. Even Morning Joe has moved to the left over the years. However, there are unbiased sources that tend to get hate from both sides, such as PBS. I’ve noticed they walk a very fine line, but if there is any criticism one way or the other, they immediately get bashed for being biased. In truth, they’re probably the least so. PBS is a good example of personal bias regarding the mainstream media. There is a tendency in some people to only prefer news outlets that confirm their own personal bias. If they see Donald Trump as the savior of the U.S., then no amount of truthful reporting is going to change their mind. PBS does a piece discussing Trump’s promises, does based on reliable sources, history, science and realities, and concludes that such and such promises are unrealistic and undoable. Rabid conservatives who make a living trashing anything having to do with liberals, immediately proclaim PBS biased, and call for defunding. Anyone living in the conservative echo chamber agree, and begin a protest. PBS does an evenhanded but critical piece on Hillary Clinton, using reliable sources, history, science and realities, and concludes many of her promises are unattainable. Rabid liberals proclaim PBS a conservative shill. The extreme left demands it gets defunded. I’m a liberal, but not so extreme that I don’t value the different sides. This is not true of many. I’ll wager, though, that most of those rabidly biased tend to sit to the right of center to varying degrees. I can go into the psychology of political leanings to support my claim, but it would make this answer a lot longer. Personal bias tends to color our perception of how biased a news source is. If a person is conservative, and the source agrees with that persons beliefs, that person tends to think the source is being fair. Otherwise, countering a belief makes the source biased, regardless of the truth. Same goes for liberals. No media outlet is 100 percent unbiased, and the degree and type of bias can vary from program to program. But, there are some outlets the try to be more fair than others. If you are only getting your news and information from a few sources, and you feel they mostly agree with how you think, then those outlets are demonstrably very much biased. It means you’re not getting the whole story. This is the case for too many these days, and one of the reasons we’ve become so divided. We all think we’re completely right, and our media choices confirm that.

The idea that MSM (Mainstream Media) is Liberal is utterly fallacious but almost all are biased. The media is a tool of the Establishment and owned and controlled by multi-billion dollar corporations that have a clear agenda as well as an almost unconscious culture that permeates almost everyone involved. The agenda of these corporate forces is established at the top executive level and disseminated throughout the organization. Most outlets have essentially the same agenda almost without exception. They want to maximize profits — remember these corporations represent far more than just the news, they represent many business interests profit and power. To that end they attempt to entertain and inform to the extent it furthers their organizational objectives and cater to those who constitute the majority of their audience — they are the establishment. We must understand first that there is a large difference in what are Social and Fiscal positions that range from Left to Right. It is quite common for a news outlet to be socially on the Left while being Center Right or Right in all other areas and this applies to most MSM. Examples of political social issues include abortion, civil rights, such as minority rights, women’s rights, gay rights, transgender rights and a host of issues that apply to acceptance of social diversity. On the other hand fiscal policy applies to policy that impacts corporate regulation, wage inequality, taxes, war and in general the ability of the rich and powerful to continue to enrich themselves and control government. It should be understood that it is in the best interests of big business to be, in general socially on the Left, while remaining fiscally on the Right, and best suits the needs of the establishment when they are socially on the Left, appear fiscally in the Center. This enables the establishment to appear to be on the Left and embrace diversity, meaning all consumer groups, while also maintaining power and control fiscally. Control is best accomplished when messaging is mixed and falls within what is considered societal norms. Trump would be far more to the liking of all MSM if he kept his radical Right wing fiscal policy without sounding like a crazed Right Wing dictator who is unstable.. Note how large tax breaks for corporations that cost billions of dollars are rarely questioned but paying for healthcare is always questioned.. This is almost ubiquitous and is where you see almost all MSM outlets following the same pattern. Fox News is the exception here in many respects and they land to the Right on social positions and fiscal positions, however there are even outliers within Fox who report the news in a fairly balanced manner like Shepard Smith. Fox disseminates and is responsible for more false information than any other MSM outlet while Fox viewers are the least educated and are the most uninformed among all MSM outlets. CNN is closer to the Left on social concerns but are closer to Center Right on all other issues. Recently CNN hired Sarah Isgur Flores, a Trump Republican spokeswoman to help with the network’s political coverage and in 2016 hired Corey Lewandowski who worked on the Trump campaign. Neither are Journalists. These kinds of hires show the true nature of these kinds of outlets who enjoy the appearance of being “Liberal” according to many but are far from it. MSNBC is the closest to the Left among the big three MSM outlets but even MSNBC has clear Center Right bias and follows the same patterns as most of the rest of MSM. Exceptions like Rachel Maddow, Chris Hayes and some others give the network the appearance of being genuinely Left but even these Lefties, for example, never mentioned the West Virginia Teachers Strike, a rather glaring omission. MSNBC like the others love Center-Right candidates that offer a return to the 80s and 90s while they minimize true Progressive candidates. To see the true nature of the messaging that is pumped out we need only look at how Progressive policy positions are minimized by all three of these MSM outlets. Even as I write this MSNBC who is supposedly Liberal is minimizing Bernie Sanders and suggesting that his ideas are old, dated and useless against Trump. This claim is supremely false and easily debunked. All the new faces in Congress making news did so with nearly the very same policies and ideas. If that isn’t enough one need only see how much money Sanders is raising from small donors while leading the polls among other Dem candidates. Yet somehow to so many MSNBC commentators this is old, ineffectual and will fail against Trump. According to their thinking Hillary was the perfect weapon against Trump, yet clearly this was not the case. By comparison the largest online Progressive media outlet “The Young Turks” does a great job of covering politics without a Center Right bias and tries to cover things truthfully. Regardless of your affiliation take a listen to them for a comparison and read on what is missing from so called Left MSM outlets. MSM questions like “How are you going to pay for that?” are almost always applied to social programs, but not applied to welfare for the rich. We don’t hear these questions applied to war or big breaks for Corporations. We do hear this asked constantly about programs like Medicare for All, a single payer healthcare options that reflects existing programs on almost all other developed nations.. We don’t hear how families go bankrupt trying to pay for medical costs, we don’t question bailouts for banks, we don’t question spending more on war than the next ten biggest nations. Or hear about how they tell employees having a tough time making ends meet to go get food stamps, etc. And this is not uncommon… Go take a look at how much in taxes many of the largest companies paid last year, or pick a big corporate name or bank at random and go look up their Corporate Rap Sheet online and see how long a list they have.. You won’t hear this kind of reporting in your “Liberal Media” so just how “Liberal” are they really? This is the true bias in the MSM, the bias for big business and big money. Yes most of the media embraces things like gay rights and civil rights because if they didn’t it would cost them. Back in the 1980s several members from the Soviet Information Ministry, came to visit the United States and met with those who worked for similar agencies here in the US, like CIA and others.. They reportedly stated their amazement at the immense effectiveness of the “messaging” used in the United States, they said, “It’s simply amazing what you have accomplished here.” The representatives from the US asked what they meant… They said, “Everyone here thinks exactly the same way, it’s an amazing accomplishment.” They went on to say, “In the Soviet Union the people know that all our messaging is propaganda — but here in the US the people don’t even think propaganda exists..” So there you have it… If you want to believe that a politician or a reporter is Left or Liberal because they’re a registered Democrat fine. But try listening carefully to what they say or don’t say. Look where the money is coming from, be they a politician with big corporate donors or a MSM figure with a big corporation. The culture in media in the US is nowhere near the Left. Reality check: The United States is an outlier among First World nations — the US favors big money and big business above all. Allowing and enforcing ideas that the MSM are Liberal or unbiased is all part of the image they want Americans to buy into because it enforces message control. This is how big money and power protects itself, in the past and today in 2019.

Well, let’s get the conservatives out of the way first: They are wrong, because the campaign to accuse the media of having a “liberal” bias is based on two things that are just as wrong: Conservatives are too often defending the status quo, which means they are defending injustice, racism, misogyny, homophobia, unfair or unsafe business practices, climate theory deniers and many other positions that cannot be defended by facts (climate change denial) or are supported much more poorly than they wish (trickle down economics). As a result, when the mainstream media simply covers these subjects, they tend to produce content that supports progressive ideas. That is not a bias.The conservative “liberal bias” campaign itself is indeed just that: a deliberate campaign to undermine the credibility of the mainstream media so as to keep conservatives and conservative-leaners in a controlled stream of conservative-friendly spin (Fox News) or outright misinformation (Breitbart).“…two events in the early 1960s convinced the right that creating conservative media wasn’t enough to achieve balance. Conservatives would also have to discredit existing media.” “The Conservative War on Liberal Media Has a Long History” Liberals do not claim that the mainstream media is “biased” in the same way that conservatives do, although there is always legitimate criticism about the potential suppressing of stories that cause problems for advertisers or other well-connected entities. However, the primary criticism from liberals in the present day is that the mainstream media, now owned by a handful of giant corporations, has become so obsessed with maintaining ratings that they are biased towards false equivalency: allowing two viewpoints of wildly mismatched credibility exist as if they “balance” each other. Fox News is, of course, the worst offender in that they have to entertain InfoWars-level absurdities as “news” in order to “balance” stories where the facts might prove liberals are right. However, the major networks also give equal time to credible and not-so-credible spokespersons (and rarely challenge either) in order to avoid controversy and lose ratings—except when a sensational, ratings-goosing story overrides their caution. This explains how Donald Trump got millions of dollars in free coverage and coverage of complex, real issues suffered as a result. False equivalence: how 'balance' makes the media dangerously dumb | Bob Garfield

Bias is a complicated term. It is one which most people fundamentally misunderstand or abuse. First: every source has bias. This bias may be meaningless, but everything has bias. Second: there are multiple kinds of biases. “Conservatives” seem to claim disagreements with their arguments as being “fake news.” Most of the time this doesnt hold up, and when a story is inaccurate or incorrect, it is usually retracted post-haste by reputable news agencies. [Looking at you fox news for not doing this] A story being incorrect or inaccurate doesnt intrinsically mean a network is biased. It is something that simply happens. Humans screw things up. Screwing things up intentionally and repeatedly however is an issue. This can be due to political leanings, or merely sensationalism. These are two very different biases. And they at times may overlap. News agencies typically have a range of topics they are more focused on or dedicated to. This is a form of bias. It does not alone discredit the news agency to have a specialty area. So long as it is accurate and intellectually honest in presentation. [You can use accurate information in dishonest ways.] Some agencies are blatantly slanted and biased in their writing. They will use loaded language, rhetorical tricks and other dishonest methods to get you on board. Most of what conservatives consider “left wing media” does not fall into this category. But of course the media a large place. [Also, most of what conservatives consider to be left is actually centre.] Opinion pieces are also typically strongly biased. Most moderates/liberals would considerthe NYT a noteworthy source. However, the opinion sections are absolute junk 99.59% of the time. And they function on a similar level to fox news, which failed qualifications of being a news agency in certain countries outside the states - where it is instead only able to be listed as entertainment. In personal experience, reading through numerous publications, I have found problematically biased publications on the left and the right. I have found that the right considers the centre and the left both as “liberal” in recent times at least. Many of the publications with the most overt and pushy biases however seem to lean rightwing, with a handful of exceptions. I believe this has to do with the education factor. Increased education increases the odds you are “liberal.” less education is generally more heavily correlated with being conservative. This also has to do with exposure to the world. And there are anomolies, certain fields may lean one way or another. Critical thinking and the ability to accurately assess information independantly is thus important. This is what they seek to teach in schools because it means you are less susceptible to being misled. I follow some right-leaning and left-leaning publications. I do so based on their veracity and ability to deliver content honestly. I follow multiple organisations because it is difficult for one organisation to cover every variety of topic and I wish to push out that form of selection bias. I could give you a non-comprehnsive list of respectable sources. And sure you could probably cherry pick examples regardless of the source. Instead however, i think its best to invest yourself into advancing critical thinking and analyses of such texts. I will say its important to consider who is telling the story and why, what is their background? What are they saying and what are they leaving out? How accurate is their information? Do I have the skills to adequately assess this situation, or oughtnt i postpone judgement until a later date. List of cognitive biases - Wikipedia Bias (statistics) - Wikipedia List of fallacies - Wikipedia RationalWiki is another great source to look into topics. It covers extensively bias and common argument/debate maltactics. Factcheckers are also your friend. Fact checkers purpose is to find the original claim and source to try the veracity of a claim. There should be a link included to the primary source. The primary source is what you need in concluding veracity. Of course, learning about your own biases and weaknesses is an involved process and could take time. It will make you a stronger more accurate person, and like most things worth doing it will take some effort and isnt an overnight ordeal. But slow and steady wins the race!

Both. And neither. The media isn't biased. Individuals within the media are biased. News reporters may or may not be biased, but the best ones are fact based and either explicitly state their biases (allowing the viewer/reader evaluate those biases) or bury them entirely and not allow them to impact the story. Same goes for writers, actors, executives, etc. They likely have individual biases, but there's not a coordinated effort aside from peer pressure in whatever your particular social circle may be. The biggest bias in the media is the bias towards making money. At the end of the day, media organizations are businesses. They exist to turn a profit. So decisions are made based on what will increase viewership and raise revenue (whether that be ad sales or ticket sales). So the news focuses on style and scandal rather than substance. Movies focus on either broadening appeal or catering to core demographics. And the people who dislike those decisions, whether they are in news, radio, music, television, or cinema, tout it as evidence of some sort of bias that excludes them rather than acknowledging that it was a simple business decision intended to make money from someone else. I don't particularly enjoy a lot of the shows my kid watches, but that's not because PBS has an anti-adult bias in the morning. We accept that is simply a demographic decision. But when it comes to things like politics, gender/race representation, or any number of other things, we blame bias. Because acknowledging that it's a business decision means also acknowledging that there's enough people that disagree with us that those people are worth catering to. And that's scary for people who dislike when people think differently.

Both liberals and conservatives claim the mainstream media is biased. Who is right? Why or why not? They’re both right, but there’s a silliness to this whole debate. People seem to believe that there’s a gold standard for the non-biased media and there are just some bad journalists that deviate from it. But when people are involved there will be bias. If the bias doesn’t exist in the stories themselves, it exists in the editorial decisions about what’s worth reporting on. The reality is that most news organizations exhibit some bias. [1]  These rankings from Allsides are the product of an ongoing research project to measure bias in media. They do this through a factor of voting participation accumulated from both stories as well as general impressions of news organizations. This screenshot of a snippet of M and N should reveal some common news outlets and what I would hope are expected bias leanings. To suppose that the media is heavily liberal or heavily conservative is counterproductive as there is a spectrum of bias across the mainstream media. AllSides has even shown that there is varying amounts of bias within the same organizations:  Fox’s editorial content is considered more right leaning than its general news desk. CNN, as well, fits a similar pattern. Different editors, different selections of what to share, different bias ratings.  They’re both right, but they’re also both wrong in how much it matters. As consumers of media, its on us to be aware of bias in reporting and to make choices about what we consume so we don’t find ourselves isolated in an echo chamber making wild rationalizations about how the “others” are somehow uniquely amoral or corrupt. They are both right. I was lucky enough in this life to have had two outstanding history teachers in high school. Both of them taught about bias and about how all human communications contain bias. One of them felt it was his personal mission to ensure that everyone who passed his class could identify bias. On a typical news article, you will find about three or four sentences of fact along with several paragraphs of fluff, extrapolations, and reactions. As free human beings, it is our duty to be able to differentiate all of the above. It is our own responsibilities to ensure that we are separating the facts from the opinions before we make our own objective opinions. Bias has the opposite effect on me than it has on most people. When I see bias, it turns me off to the claim that is being made. I'm kind of a contrarian by nature, so any time I see something that is too good to be true, I spend time researching it to find out if it is true. The fact is, if you are getting your news from social media, most of it is incorrect. If you are getting your news from traditional media sources, slightly less of it is incorrect. The only reliable way to get news is to work for it, and the internet has made that extremely easy for us to do. Unfortunately, the internet has also made it extremely easy for us to get lazy as well. The masses simply accept regurgitated, spoon-fed snippets without any regard for whether they are true or not. As a result, we have elected the kind of president we deserve.

No. Is it better than the alternative of state-run media? Hell yes. At least now we have thousands of vying media companies, making it possible to spot and discern biases. In the case of state-run media, you are left with only a few very biased sources controlled by the currently ruling party. As such, they will maintain a slight (or large) bent on their regular, self-proclaimed unbiased pieces, and offer up opinion pieces from the other side. The difference is, they don’t denote the inherent opinion in articles matching their viewers’ leanings. This way, they can both make more money AND point to these opinion pieces and say, “See! We’re not biased”. Quite shrewd. Now, all that being said, the modern internet-based media landscape is largely dominated by the progressive ideology, because they are usually more connected in the online blogosphere. This is also why pollsters on left-leaning news sites were nearly universally taken off-guard with Trump won the presidency. All of their subscribers, in their man-made echo chambers, supported Hillary naturally, so it would be simple to overlook the fact than many people didn’t like her. Now, a good amount of money has been made appealing to the previously nearly unacknowledged conservative minority in the younger generations. Also note that articles have become a commodity. Often, whoever breaks a story first makes nearly all of the cash flow (and with the internet, it can come down to seconds). As such, fact-checking has taken a backseat to clicks and speed.

This question gets at a phenomenon known as the hostile media effect. In the 1980s, social psychologist Robert Vallone attempted to study perceptions of media bias. He and his team recruited people with pro-Arab views and pro-Israel views to participate in a study that had them view media reports of the bombing of a US Marines barracks in Lebanon. After viewing the coverage, those with a pro-Arab stance viewed the news coverage as ani-Arab. Those with pro-Israel sentiments viewed the coverage as pro-Arab. So what was that all about? Human beings have a pronounced tendency to prefer information and evidence that’s favorable to our pre-existing point of view, while rejecting evidence that is unfavorable to our pre-existing views. This bias is known as ‘confirmation bias,’ and it means that we, as media consumers, are predisposed to react negatively to any information that undermines our pre-existing opinons or ideologies. So we may label those who present contrary information as biased, but when we see bias in others, it may actually be the case that our own bias leads us to to label others as biased. This isn’t to say that there are no biases in the media reporting. Any time we apply a narrative to data points (something reporters do all the time), we choose the data points to include in our story and we choose explanations that link those data points. This process is subject to our pre-existing beliefs and understandings of how the world works. We decide which facts matter and we decide how the facts are linked into an overarching story. We can try very hard not to be biased, question ourselves, really challenge our own assumptions, but it’s exceedingly difficult to fully succeed. Some in the media strike me as pretty good at this self-challenging, and some clearly make no attempt to question their data and narrative asssumptions. Perhaps the latter occurs more often when a media outlet draws ratings and clicks by creating heat more than light. It may be a good way to make money with news, but it’s more prone to bias. On the audience side, most people don’t really challenge themselves enough to identify biases. We want be right because we want to comprehend the world, and we want good guys and bad guys defined. Being right can also be a matter of pride. But in the end, all that can get in the way of self-correction. Our own biases cloud our judgment of what we’re presented by others, whether in the media or in everyday life. So the question of who is right and who is wrong about media biase, liberals or conservatives, is too broad to reflect the reality of how biases operate. Bias is very much a case by case phenomenon that can occur on both the media side and the audience side, and it is not confined to one side of the ideological spectrum or the other.

Both are right! All media is biased. Media is made by people and all people over the age of a few weeks are biased. Bias can’t be avoided. It is an inescapable consequence of experience and learning. Fears, loves, prejudices and preferences can’t be erased from our brains, they can only be neutralized with other experiences or balanced out by different learning. Responsible journalists know their biases even better than their life partners. They work very hard to keep them from shading the facts of a story. Mostly they succeed, but perfection is impossible. Some measurable bias always creeps in. Let’s try to choose the least biased word from: Harvey walked/strode/strutted/shuffled/sauntered/stomped/strolled/paraded into the courtroom. Most would answer walked. No bias there right? But if in fact Harvey either shuffled or strutted, the use of “walked” demonstrates bias. Now measure each spoken word like this with a tight deadline and you will understand why bias can never be completely scrubbed from a story. But maybe bias has gotten stronger… Only forty years ago, news came mostly from a few respected places, usually a national TV network or a local newspaper. Competing for audience size, these media outlets depended on viewers for advertising revenue. Clear bias was bad for profits. In the eighties, the media landscape widened with cable television and talk radio. Audiences loved this. They were suddenly free to choose news like a child chooses to eat an apple or a candy bar. People loved the sugar content in “news” that confirms and strengthens their world view. Candy bars are easier to sell than apples. Along came the Internet with its ability to profile and target audiences. Almost overnight, segmentation of audiences became a competitive advantage instead of a cost of doing business. Media outlets and businesses learned that they earn more from a consumer when they know their orientation (political and otherwise). Now in 2019, there are more flavors of news than ice cream. Bias is a product feature of human audiences sold by media companies to advertisers. A few cynical (notice my bias in this word?) media innovators gained market share by camouflaging opinion as news and manipulating the watcher’s emotions to get them addicted to the natural adrenaline and endorphin highs associated with outrage. It has gone a bit far in my opinion, but that is always a danger when profit-driven enterprises deliver public services in a loosely-regulated market (and yes – I believe the news is a public service).
